name: Global Human Settlement Layer
description: GHSL provides analysis ready, global, geospatial data reporting about the presence of population and human settlements

sdgs.sdg: SDG1: End Poverty in all its forms everywhere
sdgs.relevance:
There are a number of SDG indicators that require an urban-rural disaggregation, for example SDG 1.1.1. The GHSL data were used to develop the Degree of Urbanisation method to delineate cities, urban and rural areas. The UN Statistical Commission endorsed thin in 2020 for international comparison including the SDGs

There are a number of SDG indicators that require an urban-rural disaggregation, for example SDG 2.4.1 The GHSL data were used to develop the Degree of Urbanisation method to delineate cities, urban and rural areas. The UN Statistical Commission endorsed thin in 2020 for international comparison including the SDGs

There are a number of SDG indicators that require an urban-rural disaggregation, for example SDG 3.3.1. The GHSL data were used to develop the Degree of Urbanisation method to delineate cities, urban and rural areas. The UN Statistical Commission endorsed thin in 2020 for international comparison including the SDGs

There are a number of SDG indicators that require an urban-rural disaggregation, for example SDG 4.5.1. The GHSL data were used to develop the Degree of Urbanisation method to delineate cities, urban and rural areas. The UN Statistical Commission endorsed thin in 2020 for international comparison including the SDGs

In this article, the GHSL population data were used to assess the number of people with access to water. https://ucl.scienceopen.com/hosted-document?doi=10.14324/111.444/ucloe.000026

The GHSL data on population and settlements can be used to assess the number of people with access to electricity disaggregated by urban and rural share. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rser.2021.111282

The GHSL data on population and settlements can measure the rural population with access to an all weather road. https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/tgis.12721

GHSL data allow calculating directly the SDG 11.3.1 (land use efficiency). The data are also used for generating information on SDG 11.6.2 (air quality in cities) and SDG 11.7.1 (urban green). http://dx.doi.org/10.3390/su11205674

openStandards: TIFF for raster data or SHP for vector data and CSV for spreadsheet data. https://ghsl.jrc.ec.europa.eu/about.php
bestPractices:
The GHSL data are following the FAIR data principles:

- They are findable

each of the data sets is linked to a DOI and comes with a standardised data set description in the JRC data catalogue (see GHSL data collection in the catalogue: https://data.jrc.ec.europa.eu/collection/ghsl)

- They are accessible

because not registration whatsoever is needed to access the data.

- They are interoperable

because they use open data exchange formats like TIFF for raster data or SHP for vector data and CSV for spreadsheet data.

- They are reusable
because the licensing allows for wide reusability

dataPrivacySecurity.collectsPII: PII data is NOT collected NOT stored and NOT distributed.

userContent.contentManagement: Content is NOT collected NOT stored and NOT distributed.

privacy.privacyCompliance: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in the European Union
